what: Overview of the Analytical Workflow in QuAnTeTrack
title: QuAnTeTrack
text: QuAnTeTrack package (Quantitative Analysis Tetrapod Trackways) provides structured comprehensive workflow analyzing trackway data, facilitating assessment paleoecological paleoethological hypotheses. workflow integrates various functions data digitization, loading, exploratory analysis, statistical testing, simulation, similarity assessment, intersection detection, clustering. pipeline aims help researchers reconstruct, compare, interpret movement patterns behavioral dynamics trackmakers.

title: QuAnTeTrack
text: first step involves digitizing trackway data using TPS software suite, particularly: tpsUtil (Rohlf, 2008): compiling converting .TPS files. tpsDig (Rohlf, 2009): digitizing footprint coordinates trackways. digitization process ensure footprints consistently recorded across tracks. process essential converting raw images structured data analysis.

previous_headings: Overview of the Analytical Workflow in QuAnTeTrack
title: QuAnTeTrack
text: digitized, data loaded QuAnTeTrack using tps_to_track() function. function: Reads .TPS files containing digitized footprints within tracks. Extracts organizes data structured track R objects. Handles missing footprints interpolation required. Converts raw data real-world measurements using user-specified scales. resulting track R objects contain: Trajectories: Interpolated pathways derived midpoints footprints. Footprints: Original digitized points metadata track. Additionally, dataset extensive, users can utilize subset_track() function isolate specific tracks focused analysis. step helps avoid computational overhead allows customized analyses selected trajectories.

title: QuAnTeTrack
text: testing specific hypotheses, users perform initial exploration data. includes: Visual Inspection Tracks (plot_track()): Generates visualizations trackways footprints inspect overall structure. function offers various modes: Plotting footprints Plotting tracks Plotting footprints tracks Parameter Calculation (track_param()): Calculates essential movement parameters, including: Step lengths Turning angles Total distance track length Sinuosity Straightness Velocity Calculation (velocity_track()): Estimates velocities relative stride lengths track, applying formulas based empirical studies. step crucial understanding speed dynamics comparing across different trackmakers scenarios. Visualization Velocity Patterns (plot_velocity()): Provides detailed view velocity relative stride length changes along track. visualization essential identifying patterns acceleration, deceleration, steady movement. Direction Analysis (plot_direction()): Provides various visualization options explore trackway directionality: Boxplots step directions Polar histograms step directions average directions Faceted plots comparing multiple tracks functions help identify general patterns irregularities data proceeding formal statistical testing.

text: assess whether tracks exhibit distinct movement patterns, following statistical tests can applied: Compares mean velocities across tracks using ANOVA, Kruskal-Wallis, GLM. Performs pairwise comparisons necessary. Provides visualizations velocity distributions across different tracks. Applies Spearman’s rank correlation detect trends acceleration, deceleration, steady movement along track. Uses ANOVA, Kruskal-Wallis, Generalized Linear Models (GLM) compare mean directions across tracks. Performs pairwise comparisons necessary. statistical tests allow researchers rigorously compare quantify movement characteristics, providing foundation hypothesis testing.

previous_headings: Overview of the Analytical Workflow in QuAnTeTrack
title: QuAnTeTrack
text: simulate_track() function generates simulated trajectories based different movement models test specific hypotheses. Three models available: Directed Model: Represents highly constrained, purposeful movement along consistent direction. Constrained Model: Generates correlated random walks, suitable partially directed movement. Unconstrained Model: Represents fully random exploratory movement. models can informed geological data (e.g., sedimentology, paleogeomorphology, etc.) test influence environmental constraints movement. example, natural barriers features inferred geological evidence may restrict range simulated paths. plot_sim() function overlays simulated tracks actual trajectories, allowing users visually assess well different models replicate observed track patterns. visual comparison essential evaluating realism simulated tracks.

previous_headings: Overview of the Analytical Workflow in QuAnTeTrack
title: QuAnTeTrack
text: QuAnTeTrack package offers several functions aimed comparing similarity intersection metrics two actual tracks. metrics evaluated simulated datasets determine probability observing similarity intersection counts scenarios independent (non-coordinated) movement. Dynamic Time Warping (simil_DTW_metric()): Compares trajectories based optimal alignment points, allowing variable path lengths. Fréchet Distance (simil_Frechet_metric()): Measures similarity comparing overall shape trajectories, focusing global rather local alignment. Track Intersections (track_intersection()): Identifies counts unique intersections tracks, can indicate interaction coordinated movement.

Helps filter relevant datasets applying similarity metrics. Informs selection appropriate simulation models identifying common movement characteristics.

title: QuAnTeTrack
text: tps_to_track() function essential component QuAnTeTrack package, designed transform raw .TPS files containing digitized trackway data structured track objects. tool particularly useful reconstructing trackways footprints digitized using TPS software suite, tpsUtil tpsDig. function reads raw .TPS files, extracts coordinate data, processes generate track objects compatible analytical tools provided QuAnTeTrack. tps_to_track() function reads .TPS files track represented series (x, y) coordinates stored separate images. data points processed generate trajectory coordinates calculating midpoints consecutive footprints. trajectories serve reconstructed pathways, allowing users analyze overall movement patterns. missing footprints encountered, function can interpolate positions based locations adjacent footprints specified side (left right) initial footprint. Several arguments provided customize data handling. file argument specifies path .TPS file, scale argument allows users define scale factor (meters per pixel) convert coordinates real-world measurements. account missing footprints, missing argument specifies whether interpolation required, NAs argument provides matrix detailing footprints need interpolation. Additionally, R.L.side argument identifies whether first footprint track belongs left right side, essential dealing incomplete trackways. function generates track object consisting two main components: Trajectories Footprints. Trajectories element contains list interpolated trajectories, trajectory represents series midpoints calculated consecutive footprints. Footprints element comprises list data frames original footprint coordinates, associated metadata (image reference ID), indicator specifying whether footprint actual inferred. resulting track object provides comprehensive framework organizing digitized trackway data, making compatible various analytical functions within QuAnTeTrack package. structured data format enables users perform advanced analyses calculating movement parameters, testing hypotheses trackmaker behavior, comparing tracks using similarity metrics. transforming raw data structured objects, tps_to_track() function serves foundational step broader analytical pipeline provided QuAnTeTrack.

title: QuAnTeTrack
text: , TPS files (PaluxyRiver.tps MountTom.tps) loaded using system.file() function ensure compatibility across systems. approach necessary files stored internal data within package (specifically, inst/extdata/ folder). Using system.file() ensures files can accessed regardless user’s operating system working directory, making vignette fully portable reproducible. converted track objects using tps_to_track() function. scale argument used set coordinate scaling factor. PaluxyRiver dataset, footprints missing, missing argument set FALSE NAs = NULL. MountTom dataset, footprints missing, missing argument set TRUE, missing footprints specified using NAs matrix. Additionally, R.L.side argument provided specify side first footprint track (either “R” right “L” left). users working data, replace system.file("extdata", "PaluxyRiver.tps", package = "QuAnTeTrack") system.file("extdata", "MountTom.tps", package = "QuAnTeTrack") file paths .TPS files (e.g., "C:/path///PaluxyRiver.tps" "C:/path///MountTom.tps").
code: PaluxyRiver <- tps_to_track(   system.file("extdata", "PaluxyRiver.tps", package = "QuAnTeTrack"),   scale = 0.004341493,   missing = FALSE,   NAs = NULL ) MountTom <- tps_to_track(   system.file("extdata", "MountTom.tps", package = "QuAnTeTrack"),   scale = 0.004411765,   missing = TRUE,   NAs = matrix(c(7, 3), nrow = 1, ncol = 2),   R.L.side = c(     "R", "L", "L", "L", "R", "L", "R", "R", "L", "L", "L", "L", "L",      "R", "R", "L", "R", "R", "L", "R", "R", "R", "R"   ) )

title: QuAnTeTrack
text: plot_track() function versatile tool designed visualize track footprint data various ways, providing flexible approach examining presenting trackway datasets. function generates customizable plots using ggplot2 package, allowing users inspect individual tracks, footprints, combination . adjusting various plotting parameters, users can tailor visualizations highlight specific aspects dataset, individual track paths, footprint shapes, colors. plot_track() function allows users choose three plotting modes: plotting footprints, interpolated trackways, combination . controlled plot argument, can set "Footprints", "Tracks", "FootprintsTracks" (default). footprints tracks plotted using different layers, footprints represented points tracks represented lines. Additional customization options include changing colors, sizes, shapes, transparency plotted elements. Users can provide vector colors via colours argument, allows different tracks plotted different colors. cex.f cex.t arguments control sizes footprint points track lines, respectively. shape.f argument allows users specify shapes footprint points, alpha.f, alpha.t, alpha.l arguments control transparency footprints, track lines, labels, respectively. plot_track() function also supports addition labels individual tracks. plot.labels argument set TRUE, labels displayed start track, label text determined labels argument. labels provided, function automatically generates labels based track names. Users can adjust label size using cex.l argument control padding around labels box.p argument. plot_track() function returns ggplot object, can customized using additional ggplot2 functions. allows users enhance plots additional layers, themes, annotations needed. function especially useful comparing multiple trackways , providing comprehensive view track distribution, direction, spacing. also allows users produce clean visualizations suitable presentation publication.

title: QuAnTeTrack
text: default, plot_track() displays footprints interpolated trajectories. useful getting general overview track corresponding interpolated pathways.   visualize footprint data without interpolated trajectories, use plot = "Footprints" argument. particularly useful want inspect original footprint positions without influence interpolated tracks.   want focus interpolated trackways without displaying footprints, use plot = "Tracks" argument. visualization helps analyze continuity pattern movement.
code: plot_track(PaluxyRiver) plot_track(MountTom) plot_track(PaluxyRiver, plot = "Footprints") plot_track(MountTom, plot = "Footprints") plot_track(PaluxyRiver, plot = "Tracks") plot_track(MountTom, plot = "Tracks")

title: QuAnTeTrack
text: plot_track() function also allows various customizations enhance visualization. examples illustrating customizations:
code: labels <- paste("Track", seq_along(MountTom[[1]])) plot_track(MountTom, plot.labels = TRUE, labels = labels, cex.l = 4, box.p = 0.3, alpha.l = 0.7) plot_track(PaluxyRiver, plot = "Footprints", colours = c("red", "orange"), shape.f = c(15, 18))

c} + b^2 \right) \right]^{-0.5} : pp mean step length (meters), cc mean cosine turning angles (radians), bb coefficient variation step length (meters). straightness index calculated ratio D/LD/L, DD beeline distance first last points trajectory, LL total path length. index particularly useful comparing efficiency directed walks, suitable random trajectories, index tends towards zero increasing steps. track_param() function returns list lists, sublist contains computed parameters corresponding track. parameters include: turning angles, mean turning angle, standard deviation turning angles, distance, length, step lengths, mean step length, standard deviation step length, sinuosity straightness. reference direction calculating angles considered along positive x-axis, angles measured counterclockwise. computed parameters returned structured format, allowing users process visualize data needed. track_param() function provides valuable insights structure efficiency trackmaker movements, making crucial tool analyzing fossil trackways.

title: QuAnTeTrack
text: plot_direction() function provides comprehensive approach visualizing direction data track R objects. allows users generate various types plots effectively compare examine directionality within datasets. available plotting styles highly customizable, making function versatile different types directional analysis. function supports four primary plotting styles, specified plot_type argument. "boxplot" option displays distribution step directions across tracks boxplots, providing overview directionality variations showing medians, quartiles, potential outliers. "polar_steps" option generates polar histograms visualize frequency steps within various directional bins, making particularly useful examining spread density step directions around central point highlighting dominant movement trends. "polar_average" style also produces polar histograms, focuses average directions per track rather individual steps. summarization approach offers simplified comparison overall trends across multiple tracks. Finally, "faceted" option creates faceted polar histograms track displayed separately within grid plots, providing clear visual comparison step directions across tracks making especially effective analyzing individual trackmaker behaviors. plot_direction() function allows users customize visualizations several arguments. angle_range argument controls width bins used polar histograms, allowing users specify desired angular resolution. y_labels_position argument useful positioning labels y-axis, especially polar plots, enhance clarity presentation. Users can also provide custom breaks y-axis using y_breaks_manual argument, defines labels placed better visualization frequency data. flexibility ensures user can tailor output suit specific analytical needs, whether examining general trends, comparing individual tracks, highlighting particular aspects directional data. generating high-quality visualizations ggplot objects, plot_direction() function allows customization using additional functions ggplot2 package. integration makes easy enhance plots annotations, themes, graphical elements. function particularly useful analyzing trackway direction data, providing valuable insights movement patterns, orientation preferences, potential group behavior.

title: QuAnTeTrack
text: Boxplots provide summary distribution directions, including median, quartiles, outliers. visualization useful comparing general directionality across tracks.   Polar plots show individual step directions radiating central point, providing detailed visualization movement patterns tracks.   Polar plot average directions averages directional data track, providing simplified overview general movement trends.   Faceted polar plots step directions display individual step directions track separate panels, allowing clearer comparison movement patterns across multiple tracks.
code: plot_direction(PaluxyRiver, plot_type = "boxplot") plot_direction(MountTom, plot_type = "boxplot") plot_direction(PaluxyRiver, plot_type = "polar_steps") plot_direction(MountTom, plot_type = "polar_steps") plot_direction(PaluxyRiver, plot_type = "polar_average") plot_direction(MountTom, plot_type = "polar_average") plot_direction(PaluxyRiver, plot_type = "faceted") plot_direction(MountTom, plot_type = "faceted")

title: QuAnTeTrack
text: plot_direction() function offers several customization options enhance visualization data: y_breaks_manual: Define custom breaks radial axis polar_average plots.  y_labels_position: Adjust position y-axis labels. can helpful fine-tuning polar plots presentation.

title: QuAnTeTrack
text: test_direction() function provides powerful statistical framework comparing mean directions across different tracks within track R object. offers three distinct methods purpose: ANOVA, Kruskal-Wallis test, Generalized Linear Models (GLM), ensuring robust analysis even assumptions data distribution variance homogeneity violated. function requires track contains three footprints included analysis, statistical tests comparing mean directions require sufficient sample size generate meaningful results. threshold ensures comparisons statistically reliable robust. using ANOVA method, function first checks normality data Shapiro-Wilk test assesses homogeneity variances using Levene’s test. assumptions violated, user advised consider Kruskal-Wallis GLM methods instead. ANOVA method compares mean directions across tracks, significant differences detected, Tukey’s HSD test applied perform post-hoc pairwise comparisons. Kruskal-Wallis test, contrast, offers non-parametric approach compares median directions across tracks applies Dunn’s test pairwise comparisons significant differences found. method particularly suitable data meet assumptions required parametric tests. Alternatively, GLM method selected, function applies Generalized Linear Model (GLM) Gaussian family compare mean directions. emmeans package used compute pairwise comparisons, adjustments multiple comparisons following Tukey’s method, offering flexible approach dealing complex data distributions deviations normality. test_direction() function returns detailed set results. provides normality results matrix containing Shapiro-Wilk test statistic p-value track, allowing user evaluate whether data follows normal distribution. function also outputs result Levene’s test, including p-value used assess whether variances across tracks homogeneous. ANOVA method selected, function delivers ANOVA table along Tukey HSD post-hoc results, enabling thorough examination differences groups. Kruskal-Wallis test, function returns overall test result alongside Dunn’s test post-hoc comparisons, providing non-parametric alternative analyzing differences central tendency. case GLM, output includes summary model fit along pairwise comparisons calculated via emmeans package, providing efficient method detect significant differences accommodating complex statistical models. flexibility comprehensiveness test_direction() function make versatile tool comparing directional data across multiple tracks. ability perform parametric, non-parametric, generalized linear model analyses ensures researchers can robustly test hypotheses related movement patterns, group behavior, ecological interactions, regardless underlying data structure.

what: Calculating Velocities and Relative Stride Lengths
title: QuAnTeTrack
text: velocity_track() function calculates velocities relative stride lengths step within series tracks. requires ‘track’ R object input, contains trajectories footprints, uses height hip track maker estimate speed. function supports two calculation methods: Method (Alexander, 1976) Method B (Ruiz & Torices, 2013), specified via method argument. default, Method applied tracks method specified. gravitational acceleration, G, set 9.8 m/s^{2} default can modified needed. function works first extracting track data calculating Euclidean distance consecutive footprints determine stride length. step, velocity calculated using one two methods. Method applies formula (Alexander, 1976): v=0.25⋅G⋅S1.67⋅H−1.17 v = 0.25 \cdot \sqrt{G} \cdot S^{1.67} \cdot H^{-1.17} vv velocity (m/s), GG gravity (m/s^{2}), SS stride length (m), HH hip height (m). method based empirical studies model relationship stride length, body size, speed general terrestrial vertebrates. coefficients 0.250.25, 1.671.67, −1.17-1.17 derived studies focused scaling relationships bipedal quadrupedal animals. Method B follows similar approach coefficient 0.2260.226 instead 0.250.25, provides refinement bipedal locomotion. formula (Ruiz & Torices, 2013): v=0.226⋅G⋅S1.67⋅H−1.17 v = 0.226 \cdot \sqrt{G} \cdot S^{1.67} \cdot H^{-1.17} relative stride length calculated ratio stride length hip height (S/HS / H), allows distinguishing different gaits according Thulborn & Wade (1984). classification follows: Walk: Relative stride <2.0< 2.0 (locomotor performance equivalent walking mammals). Trot: Relative stride 2.0≤/H≤2.92.0 \leq /H \leq 2.9 (locomotor performance equivalent trotting racking mammals). Run: Relative stride >2.9> 2.9 (locomotor performance equivalent cantering, galloping, sprinting mammals). function returns track velocity R object, structured list lists, list representing individual track. track, output includes various metrics describe calculated velocities relative stride lengths. Specifically, provides vector calculated velocities step, referred Step_velocities, measured meters per second (m/s). Additionally, function calculates Mean_velocity, represents average speed across steps, well Standard_deviation_velocity, quantifies variation velocity measurements. Maximum_velocity Minimum_velocity indicate highest lowest calculated velocities, respectively. terms relative stride lengths, function also provides vector calculated values known Step_relative_stride. average values captured Mean_relative_stride, variation described Standard_deviation_relative_stride. Moreover, highest lowest calculated relative stride lengths denoted Maximum_relative_stride Minimum_relative_stride, respectively. comprehensive output allows users thoroughly assess speed locomotion style track-makers study. function particularly useful estimating speed ancient track-makers footprints evaluating locomotion style (walking, trotting, running).

title: Quantitative Analysis of Tetrapod Trackways
text: Understanding movement behavior extinct tetrapods fundamental aspect palaeobiology, offering glimpse organisms interacted environment . Fossil trackways provide dynamic record locomotor patterns, ecological interactions, even potential social behavior. However, extracting meaningful information ancient tracks requires robust analytical tools capable processing complex datasets. Introducing QuAnTeTrack (Quantitative Analysis Tetrapod Trackways), integrated R package specifically designed facilitate semi-automated extraction palaeobiological insights fossil trackways. versatile tool allows researchers seamlessly convert digitized footprint data analytical objects apply range statistical graphical methods explore locomotor ecological hypotheses. QuAnTeTrack workflow begins data digitization, footprint coordinates recorded saved .TPS files using tools like tpsUtil tpsDig. files converted structured R objects using tps_to_track() function, transforming raw coordinates well-organized datasets can easily manipulated analyzed. data properly structured, exploratory analyses can conducted assess fundamental movement parameters. Functions like track_param() provide detailed information turning angles, track distances, step lengths, sinuosity, straightness. Simultaneously, velocity_track() function allows users estimate locomotor speed relative stride length, providing crucial insights gait locomotor performance. Visualizing results made simple functions like plot_track() plot_velocity(), generate high-quality, publication-ready graphs. Beyond exploratory analysis, QuAnTeTrack offers powerful tools statistical testing hypothesis evaluation. Functions like test_direction() test_velocity() allow users test directional consistency velocity differences among tracks, mode_velocity() assesses whether trackmakers accelerating, decelerating, maintaining steady speed along paths. central aspect package ability simulate tracks different movement models (simulate_track()). models informed geological environmental constraints, allowing researchers evaluate landscape features resource availability may influenced ancient trackmakers’ paths. plot_sim() function provides intuitive way compare simulated tracks original dataset. simulated tracks generated, QuAnTeTrack provides robust tools test ecological ethological hypotheses. Trajectory similarity can assessed Dynamic Time Warping (DTW) Fréchet distance metrics (simil_DTW_metric() simil_Frechet_metric()), potential interactions individuals can quantified using track_intersection() function. comparing metrics null models generated simulations, researchers can assess whether trackways display patterns suggestive coordinated behavior, pursuit, ecologically significant interactions. Additionally, QuAnTeTrack supports combining multiple metrics comprehensive tests hypothesis robustness using combined_prob() function. allows researchers aggregate results similarity metrics, intersection counts, statistics single overall measure similarity interaction significance. package also includes functionality cluster tracks based movement parameters (cluster_track()). tool particularly useful detecting distinct behavioral modes within dataset grouping tracks share similar movement characteristics prior analysis. Throughout workflow, QuAnTeTrack offers flexibility visualizing, testing, comparing tracks. use R’s powerful visualization tools ensures results can effectively communicated refined necessary. integrating data processing, statistical testing, simulation modeling, visualization single, user-friendly package, QuAnTeTrack provides comprehensive framework analyzing tetrapod trackways testing complex ecological behavioral hypotheses.

what: Cluster tracks based on movement parameters — cluster_track
title: Cluster tracks based on movement parameters — cluster_track
text: cluster_track() clusters trajectories based various movement velocity parameters calculated track.

title: Cluster tracks based on movement parameters — cluster_track
code: cluster_track(data, veltrack, variables)

title: Cluster tracks based on movement parameters — cluster_track
text: data 'track' R object, list consisting two elements: Trajectories: list interpolated trajectories, trajectory series midpoints consecutive footprints. Footprints: list data frames containing footprint coordinates, metadata (e.g., image reference, ID), marker indicating whether footprint actual inferred. veltrack 'track velocity' R object consisting list lists, sublist contains computed parameters corresponding track. variables character vector specifying movement parameters used clustering analysis. Valid parameter names include: "TurnAng", "sdTurnAng", "Distance", "Length", "StLength", "sdStLength", "Sinuosity", "Straightness", "Velocity", "sdVelocity", "MaxVelocity", "MinVelocity".

title: Cluster tracks based on movement parameters — cluster_track
text: 'track clustering' R object consisting list containing following elements: matrix: data frame containing movement parameters calculated track. clust: Mclust object containing results model-based clustering analysis. object provides optimal (according BIC) mixture model estimation. output components : call: matched call. data: input data matrix. modelName: character string denoting model optimal BIC occurs. n: number observations data. d: dimension data. G: optimal number mixture components. BIC: BIC values. loglik: log-likelihood corresponding optimal BIC. df: number estimated parameters. bic: BIC value selected model. icl: ICL value selected model. hypvol: hypervolume parameter noise component required, otherwise set NULL. parameters: list following components: pro: vector whose k\(^{th}\) component mixing proportion k\(^{th}\) component mixture model. missing, equal proportions assumed. mean: mean component. one component, matrix whose k\(^{th}\) column mean k\(^{th}\) component mixture model. variance: list variance parameters model. components list depend model specification. See help file mclustVariance details. z: matrix whose ,k\(^{th}\) entry probability observation test data belongs k\(^{th}\) class. classification: classification corresponding z, .e., map(z). uncertainty: uncertainty associated classification.

title: Cluster tracks based on movement parameters — cluster_track
text: cluster_track() function performs model-based clustering analysis track parameters using Mclust() function mclust package. function first filters tracks fewer four steps, tracks may provide reliable movement data. calculates various movement parameters remaining track, including turning angles, distances, lengths, sinuosity, straightness, velocities. Finally, selected movement parameters used input clustering tracks. one parameter selected, clustering performed using equal variance ("E") variable variance ("V") Gaussian models. one parameter selected, Gaussian models available mclust.options("emModelNames") considered. following movement parameters can included clustering: "TurnAng": Turning angles track, measured degrees. measures much direction movement changes step. "sdTurnAng": standard deviation turning angles, indicating variable turning angles across track. "Distance": total distance covered track, calculated sum straight-line distances consecutive points (meters). "Length": overall length track, straight-line distance starting ending points (meters). "StLength": Step lengths step track, representing far object moved two consecutive points (meters). "sdStLength": standard deviation step lengths, showing consistent steps length. "Sinuosity": measure track's winding nature, calculated ratio actual track length straight-line distance (dimensionless). "Straightness": straightness track, calculated straight-line distance divided total path length (dimensionless). "Velocity": average velocity track, calculated total distance divided time elapsed first last footprint (meters per second). "sdVelocity": standard deviation velocity, indicating much velocity fluctuates throughout track. "MaxVelocity": maximum velocity achieved track, identifying fastest point (meters per second). "MinVelocity": minimum velocity track, identifying slowest point (meters per second). cluster_track() function biological relevance identifying groups tracks similar movement parameters, providing insights ecological behavioral patterns. clustering tracks based characteristics sinuosity, velocity, turning angles, allows detecting movement patterns associated specific behaviors. can help identify tracks potentially made individuals moving together, useful investigating hypotheses gregarious behavior, predation strategies, coordinated movement. Additionally, clustering serves preliminary step similarity tests simulations, refining track selection improving hypothesis testing movement ecology studies.

what: Calculate combined probabilities of similarity or intersection metrics of tracks — combined_prob
title: Calculate combined probabilities of similarity or intersection metrics of tracks — combined_prob
text: combined_prob() calculates combined probabilities similarity intersection metrics derived different models. function uses simulation data extract p-values, providing insight significance combined metrics across various similarity assessments.

title: Calculate combined probabilities of similarity or intersection metrics of tracks — combined_prob
code: combined_prob(data, metrics = NULL)

title: Calculate combined probabilities of similarity or intersection metrics of tracks — combined_prob
text: data 'track' R object, list consisting two elements: Trajectories: list interpolated trajectories, trajectory series midpoints consecutive footprints. Footprints: list data frames containing footprint coordinates, metadata (e.g., image reference, ID), marker indicating whether footprint actual inferred. metrics list 'track similarity' /'track intersection' R objects derived different tests. tests must based number simulations.

title: Calculate combined probabilities of similarity or intersection metrics of tracks — combined_prob
text: list containing: P_values (model names) matrix p-values combined metrics across trajectories. entry represents probability observing combined metrics corresponding pair trajectories. P_values_combined (model names) numeric value representing overall probability observing combined metrics, across pairs trajectories.

title: Calculate combined probabilities of similarity or intersection metrics of tracks — combined_prob
text: combined_prob() function combines p-values derived multiple similarity metric tests intersection tests. calculates combined p-values assessing probability observing combined metrics across simulated datasets. function particularly useful comparing multiple models evaluating collective performance terms p-values.

title: Calculate combined probabilities of similarity or intersection metrics of tracks — combined_prob
text: Humberto G. Ferrón humberto.ferron@uv.es Macroevolution Functional Morphology Research Group (www.macrofun.es) Cavanilles Institute Biodiversity Evolutionary Biology Calle Catedrático José Beltrán Martínez, nº 2 46980 Paterna - Valencia - Spain Phone: +34 (9635) 44477

what: Test for steady, acceleration, or deceleration along trajectories — mode_velocity
title: Test for steady, acceleration, or deceleration along trajectories — mode_velocity
text: mode_velocity() evaluates trend velocity along trajectory applying Spearman's rank correlation test. function classifies trend "acceleration," "deceleration," "steady" based correlation p-value.

title: Test for steady, acceleration, or deceleration along trajectories — mode_velocity
code: mode_velocity(trackvel)

title: Test for steady, acceleration, or deceleration along trajectories — mode_velocity
text: trackvel list element corresponds track contains vector velocity relative stride length data.

title: Test for steady, acceleration, or deceleration along trajectories — mode_velocity
text: list element corresponds trajectory input trackvel contains: correlation: result Spearman correlation test, including correlation coefficient p-value. trend: classification trend "Acceleration," "Deceleration," "Steady" based p-value correlation coefficient. trajectory fewer 3 steps, entry contains message "Less three steps."

title: Test for steady, acceleration, or deceleration along trajectories — mode_velocity
text: mode_velocity() function performs following operations: Spearman's Rank Correlation Test: non-parametric test assesses strength direction monotonic relationship two variables. require assumptions normality data linear relationship velocity step number. uses ranks rather raw values, making robust outliers suitable detecting general trends (acceleration deceleration) velocity data. Function Operation: trajectory trackvel list, function calculates Spearman correlation coefficient associated p-value velocity step number. Based p-value correlation coefficient, classifies trend "acceleration," "deceleration," "steady." trajectory contains fewer 3 steps, function returns message indicating insufficient data correlation analysis. Advantages: non-parametric nature allows flexibility data distributions reduced sensitivity outliers compared parametric tests. Effective detecting monotonic trends (either increasing decreasing) correlation statistically significant. Limitations: May unreliable small sample sizes (e.g., fewer 3 steps), providing potentially non-informative results. capture magnitude change provide detailed insights rate acceleration deceleration. Identifies monotonic trends based statistical significance distinguish different types monotonic relationships (e.g., steady acceleration vs. abrupt changes). Interpretation Results: Acceleration: p-value less 0.05 Spearman correlation coefficient positive. Deceleration: p-value less 0.05 Spearman correlation coefficient negative. Steady: p-value greater equal 0.05, indicating significant monotonic relationship. Usage Considerations: Ensure trajectory trackvel sufficient number steps meaningful analysis. detailed analysis velocity trends, consider complementary methods linear non-linear regression, specialized change point detection techniques.

title: Test for steady, acceleration, or deceleration along trajectories — mode_velocity

what: Plot direction data in tracks. — plot_direction
title: Plot direction data in tracks. — plot_direction
text: plot_direction()  generates different types plots visualize direction data 'track' R objects. function allows creation boxplots, polar histograms step directions, polar histograms average directions per track, faceted polar histograms.

title: Plot direction data in tracks. — plot_direction
code: plot_direction(   data,   plot_type = "boxplot",   angle_range = 30,   y_labels_position = 90,   y_breaks_manual = NULL )

title: Plot direction data in tracks. — plot_direction
text: data 'track' R object, list consisting two elements: Trajectories: list interpolated trajectories, trajectory series midpoints consecutive footprints. Footprints: list data frames containing footprint coordinates, metadata (e.g., image reference, ID), marker indicating whether footprint actual inferred. plot_type character string indicating type plot generate. options "boxplot", "polar_steps", "polar_average", "faceted". Default "boxplot". angle_range numeric value specifying width bins (degrees) used polar plots. Default 30 degrees. y_labels_position numeric value specifying position (degrees) y-axis labels polar plots. Default 90 degrees. y_breaks_manual numeric vector specifying manual breaks y-axis polar plots. NULL, breaks calculated automatically. Default NULL.

title: Plot direction data in tracks. — plot_direction
text: ggplot object displays specified plot type. ggplot2 package used plotting.

title: Plot direction data in tracks. — plot_direction
text: plot_direction() function provides four types plots: "boxplot": boxplot showing distribution step direction values track. "polar_steps": polar plot showing frequency step different direction bins. "polar_average": polar plot showing frequency average directions per track different direction bins. "faceted": polar plot similar "polar_steps" faceted track. angle_range parameter defines bin width polar plots, y_labels_position allows adjusting position y-axis labels. y_breaks_manual parameter lets users manually specify breaks y-axis finer control appearance polar plots.

title: Plot direction data in tracks. — plot_direction
text: Humberto G. Ferrón humberto.ferron@uv.es Macroevolution Functional Morphology Research Group (www.macrofun.es) Cavanilles Institute Biodiversity Evolutionary Biology Calle Catedrático José Beltrán Martínez, nº 2 46980 Paterna - Valencia - Spain Phone: +34 (9635) 44477

title: Plot Simulated Tracks — plot_sim
text: plot_sim() creates plot visualizes simulated actual movement trajectories. function useful comparing simulated tracks generated simulate_track() observed trajectories evaluate well simulation models represent real movement patterns.

title: Plot Simulated Tracks — plot_sim
code: plot_sim(   data,   sim,   colours_sim = NULL,   alpha_sim = NULL,   lwd_sim = NULL,   colours_act = NULL,   alpha_act = NULL,   lwd_act = NULL )

title: Plot Simulated Tracks — plot_sim
text: data 'track' R object, list consisting two elements: Trajectories: list interpolated trajectories, trajectory series midpoints consecutive footprints. Footprints: list data frames containing footprint coordinates, metadata (e.g., image reference, ID), marker indicating whether footprint actual inferred. sim 'track simulation' R object, object list simulated trajectories stored 'track' R objects. colours_sim vector colors plotting set simulated trajectories. NULL, default color black ("#000000"). alpha_sim numeric value 0 1 transparency level simulated trajectories. default 0.1. lwd_sim numeric value line width simulated trajectory lines. default 0.5. colours_act vector colors plotting actual trajectories. NULL, default color black ("#000000"). alpha_act numeric value 0 1 transparency level actual trajectories. default 0.6. lwd_act numeric value line width actual trajectory lines. default 0.8.

title: Plot Simulated Tracks — plot_sim
text: ggplot object displaying simulated actual trajectories.

title: Plot Simulated Tracks — plot_sim
text: function uses ggplot2 create plot following components: Simulated trajectories displayed paths colored according colours_sim parameter, specified transparency alpha_sim line width lwd_sim. Actual trajectories overlaid colors specified colours_act, transparency level alpha_act line width lwd_act provide clear comparison.

title: Plot Simulated Tracks — plot_sim
text: Humberto G. Ferrón humberto.ferron@uv.es Macroevolution Functional Morphology Research Group (www.macrofun.es) Cavanilles Institute Biodiversity Evolutionary Biology Calle Catedrático José Beltrán Martínez, nº 2 46980 Paterna - Valencia - Spain Phone: +34 (9635) 44477

title: Plot Simulated Tracks — plot_sim
code: # Example 1: Simulate tracks using data from the Paluxy River # Default model (Unconstrained movement) # Default number of simulations (1000) simulated_tracks <- simulate_track(PaluxyRiver) #> Warning: `nsim` is NULL. Using default value of 1000. #> Warning: `model` is NULL. Defaulting to 'Unconstrained'.  # Plot simulated tracks with default settings and actual tracks plot_sim(PaluxyRiver, simulated_tracks)   # Example 2: Simulate 100 tracks using the "Directed" model, representing movement toward a # resource simulated_tracks_directed <- simulate_track(PaluxyRiver, nsim = 10, model = "Directed")  # Plot simulated tracks with specific colors and transparency for "Directed" model plot_sim(PaluxyRiver, simulated_tracks_directed,   colours_sim = c("#E69F00", "#56B4E9"),   alpha_sim = 0.4, lwd_sim = 1, colours_act = c("black", "black"), alpha_act = 0.7,   lwd_act = 2 )   # Example 3: Simulate 100 tracks using the "Constrained" model, representing movement along # a feature simulated_tracks_constrained <- simulate_track(PaluxyRiver, nsim = 10, model = "Constrained")  # Plot simulated tracks with a different color scheme and width for "Constrained" model plot_sim(PaluxyRiver, simulated_tracks_constrained,   colours_sim = c("#E69F00", "#56B4E9"),   alpha_sim = 0.6, lwd_sim = 0.1, alpha_act = 0.5, lwd_act = 2 )   # Example 4: Simulate 100 tracks using the "Unconstrained" model (random exploratory # movement) simulated_tracks_unconstrained <- simulate_track(PaluxyRiver, nsim = 10, model = "Unconstrained")  # Plot simulated tracks with default colors and increased transparency for "Unconstrained" # model plot_sim(PaluxyRiver, simulated_tracks_unconstrained,   colours_sim = c("#E69F00", "#56B4E9"),   alpha_sim = 0.2, lwd_sim = 1, colours_act = c("#E69F00", "#56B4E9"), alpha_act = 0.9,   lwd_act = 2 )   # Subsetting trajectories with four or more steps in the Mount Tom dataset sbMountTom <- subset_track(MountTom, tracks = c(1, 2, 3, 4, 7, 8, 9, 13, 15, 16, 18))  # Example 5: Simulate tracks using data from Mount Tom simulated_tracks_mt <- simulate_track(sbMountTom) #> Warning: `nsim` is NULL. Using default value of 1000. #> Warning: `model` is NULL. Defaulting to 'Unconstrained'.  # Plot simulated tracks with default settings and actual tracks from Mount Tom plot_sim(sbMountTom, simulated_tracks_mt)   # Example 6: Simulate 100 tracks using the "Directed" model for Mount Tom simulated_tracks_mt_directed <- simulate_track(sbMountTom, nsim = 10, model = "Directed")  # Plot simulated tracks with specific colors and transparency for "Directed" model for Mount # Tom plot_sim(sbMountTom, simulated_tracks_mt_directed, colours_sim = c(   "#E69F00", "#56B4E9",   "#009E73", "#F0E442", "#0072B2", "#D55E00", "#CC79A7", "#999999", "#F4A300",   "#6C6C6C", "#1F77B4" ), alpha_sim = 0.3, lwd_sim = 1.5, alpha_act = 0.8, lwd_act = 2)   # Example 7: Simulate 100 tracks using the "Constrained" model for Mount Tom simulated_tracks_mt_constrained <- simulate_track(sbMountTom, nsim = 10, model = "Constrained")  # Plot simulated tracks with different color scheme and increased line width for "Constrained" # model plot_sim(sbMountTom, simulated_tracks_mt_constrained, colours_sim = c(   "#E41A1C", "#377EB8",   "#4DAF4A", "#FF7F00", "#F781BF", "#A65628", "#FFFF33", "#8DD3C7", "#FB8072",   "#80BF91", "#F7F7F7" ), alpha_sim = 0.5, lwd_sim = 0.2, alpha_act = 0.6, lwd_act = 2)   # Example 8: Simulate 100 tracks using the "Unconstrained" model for Mount Tom simulated_tracks_mt_unconstrained <- simulate_track(sbMountTom, nsim = 10, model = "Unconstrained")  # Plot simulated tracks with a different color scheme and transparency for "Unconstrained" model plot_sim(sbMountTom, simulated_tracks_mt_unconstrained, colours_sim = c(   "#6BAED6", "#FF7F00",   "#1F77B4", "#D62728", "#2CA02C", "#9467BD", "#8C564B", "#E377C2", "#7F7F7F",   "#BCBD22", "#17BECF" ), alpha_sim = 0.2, lwd_sim = 0.5, colours_act = c(   "#6BAED6",   "#FF7F00", "#1F77B4", "#D62728", "#2CA02C", "#9467BD", "#8C564B", "#E377C2",   "#7F7F7F", "#BCBD22", "#17BECF" ), alpha_act = 1, lwd_act = 2)

title: Plot tracks and footprints — plot_track
text: plot_track() visualizes track footprint data various ways, allowing plotting trajectories, footprints, combined, customizable aesthetics.

title: Plot tracks and footprints — plot_track
code: plot_track(   data,   plot = "FootprintsTracks",   colours = NULL,   cex.f = NULL,   shape.f = NULL,   alpha.f = NULL,   cex.t = NULL,   alpha.t = NULL,   plot.labels = NULL,   labels = NULL,   box.p = NULL,   cex.l = NULL,   alpha.l = NULL )

title: Plot tracks and footprints — plot_track
text: data 'track' R object, list consisting two elements: Trajectories: list interpolated trajectories, trajectory series midpoints consecutive footprints. Footprints: list data frames containing footprint coordinates, metadata (e.g., image reference, ID), marker indicating whether footprint actual inferred. plot Type plot generate. Options "FootprintsTracks" (default), "Tracks", "Footprints". Determines elements included plot. colours vector colors used different tracks. NULL, defaults black. length vector match number tracks data. cex.f size footprint points. Default 2.5. shape.f vector shapes used footprints different tracks. NULL, defaults 19 (solid circle). length vector match number tracks data. alpha.f transparency footprint points. Default 0.5. cex.t size track lines. Default 0.5. alpha.t transparency track lines. Default 1. plot.labels Logical indicating whether add labels track. Default FALSE. labels vector labels track. NULL, labels automatically generated track names. box.p Padding around label boxes, used plot.labels TRUE. Adjusts spacing around label text. cex.l size labels. Default 3.88. alpha.l transparency labels. Default 0.5.

title: Plot tracks and footprints — plot_track
text: ggplot object displays specified plot type, including tracks, footprints, , 'track' R objects. ggplot2 package used plotting.

title: Plot tracks and footprints — plot_track
text: Humberto G. Ferrón humberto.ferron@uv.es Macroevolution Functional Morphology Research Group (www.macrofun.es) Cavanilles Institute Biodiversity Evolutionary Biology Calle Catedrático José Beltrán Martínez, nº 2 46980 Paterna - Valencia - Spain Phone: +34 (9635) 44477

title: Plot tracks and footprints — plot_track
code: # Example 1: Basic Plot with Default Settings - MountTom Dataset plot_track(MountTom)   # Example 2: Basic Plot with Default Settings - PaluxyRiver Dataset plot_track(PaluxyRiver)   # Example 3: Plot Tracks Only - MountTom Dataset plot_track(MountTom, plot = "Tracks")   # Example 4: Plot Footprints Only - PaluxyRiver Dataset plot_track(PaluxyRiver, plot = "Footprints")   # Example 5: Custom Colors for Tracks - MountTom Dataset custom_colors <- c(   "#008000", "#0000FF", "#FF0000", "#800080", "#FFA500", "#FFC0CB", "#FFFF00",   "#00FFFF", "#A52A2A", "#FF00FF", "#808080", "#000000", "#006400", "#00008B",   "#8B0000", "#FF8C00", "#008B8B", "#A9A9A9", "#000080", "#808000", "#800000",   "#008080", "#FFD700" ) plot_track(MountTom, colours = custom_colors)   # Example 6: Larger Footprints and Track Lines - PaluxyRiver Dataset plot_track(PaluxyRiver, cex.f = 5, cex.t = 2)   # Example 7: Semi-Transparent Footprints and Tracks - MountTom Dataset plot_track(MountTom, alpha.f = 0.5, alpha.t = 0.5)   # Example 8: Different Shapes for Footprints - PaluxyRiver Dataset plot_track(PaluxyRiver, shape.f = c(16, 17))   # Example 9: Plot with Labels for Tracks - MountTom Dataset labels <- paste("Track", seq_along(MountTom[[1]])) plot_track(MountTom, plot.labels = TRUE, labels = labels, cex.l = 4, box.p = 0.3, alpha.l = 0.7)   # Example 10: Custom Colors and Shapes for Footprints Only - PaluxyRiver Dataset plot_track(PaluxyRiver, plot = "Footprints", colours = c("purple", "orange"), shape.f = c(15, 18))   # Example 11: Larger Line Size & Custom Colors for Tracks Only - MountTom Dataset plot_track(MountTom, plot = "Tracks", cex.t = 1.5, colours = custom_colors)   # Example 12: Black Footprints and Tracks with Labels - PaluxyRiver Dataset plot_track(PaluxyRiver,   colours = NULL, shape.f = c(16, 16), plot.labels = TRUE,   labels = c("Saurpod", "Theropod"), cex.l = 2, alpha.l = 0.5 )

what: Plot trajectories colored by velocity or relative stride length — plot_velocity
title: Plot trajectories colored by velocity or relative stride length — plot_velocity
text: plot_velocity() creates plot trajectories, colored either velocity relative stride length 'track' 'track velocity' R objects. function uses ggplot2 package visualization allows customization line width color gradients.

title: Plot trajectories colored by velocity or relative stride length — plot_velocity
code: plot_velocity(   data,   trackvel,   param = NULL,   lwd = NULL,   colours = NULL,   legend = NULL )

title: Plot trajectories colored by velocity or relative stride length — plot_velocity
text: data 'track' R object, list consisting two elements: Trajectories: list interpolated trajectories, trajectory series midpoints consecutive footprints. Footprints: list data frames containing footprint coordinates, metadata (e.g., image reference, ID), marker indicating whether footprint actual inferred. trackvel 'track velocity' R object consisting list element corresponds track contains velocity relative stride length data. param character string specifying parameter plot. Options : "V" velocity. "RSL" relative stride length. NULL, default value "V" used. lwd Numeric. Line width plotted trajectories. Default 1. colours vector colors use gradient. Default predefined set colors. legend Logical. TRUE, legend shown. FALSE, legend removed. Default TRUE.

title: Plot trajectories colored by velocity or relative stride length — plot_velocity
text: ggplot object showing trajectories colored specified parameter.

title: Plot trajectories colored by velocity or relative stride length — plot_velocity
text: function creates plot trajectory colored based specified parameter ("V" velocity "RSL" relative stride length). ggplot2 package used plotting. color gradient parameter applied using scale_color_gradientn(). color palette can customized via colours argument.

title: Plot trajectories colored by velocity or relative stride length — plot_velocity

title: Similarity metric using Dynamic Time Warping (DTW) — simil_DTW_metric
text: simil_DTW_metric()  computes similarity metrics two trajectories using Dynamic Time Warping (DTW). allows different superposition methods align trajectories calculating DTW metric. function also supports testing simulations calculate p-values DTW distance metrics.

title: Similarity metric using Dynamic Time Warping (DTW) — simil_DTW_metric
code: simil_DTW_metric(data, test = NULL, sim = NULL, superposition = NULL)

title: Similarity metric using Dynamic Time Warping (DTW) — simil_DTW_metric
text: data 'track' R object, list consisting two elements: Trajectories: list interpolated trajectories, trajectory series midpoints consecutive footprints. Footprints: list data frames containing footprint coordinates, metadata (e.g., image reference, ID), marker indicating whether footprint actual inferred. test Logical; TRUE, function compares observed DTW distances simulated trajectories calculates p-values. Default FALSE. sim 'track simulation' R object consisting list simulated trajectories use comparison test = TRUE. superposition character string indicating method used align trajectories. Options "None", "Centroid", "Origin". Default "None".

title: Similarity metric using Dynamic Time Warping (DTW) — simil_DTW_metric
text: 'track similarity' R object consisting ofa list containing following elements: DTW_distance_metric matrix containing pairwise DTW distances trajectories. DTW_distance_metric_p_values (test TRUE) matrix containing p-values pairwise DTW distances. DTW_metric_p_values_combined (test TRUE) overall p-value combined DTW distances. DTW_distance_metric_simulations (test TRUE) list DTW distance matrices simulated dataset.

title: Similarity metric using Dynamic Time Warping (DTW) — simil_DTW_metric
text: simil_DTW_metric() function calculates similarity trajectories using Dynamic Time Warping (DTW) algorithm dtw package. dtw() function used dist.method argument set "Euclidean" computing local distances points trajectories. DTW aligns two time series minimizing cumulative distance points, creating optimal alignment despite variations length temporal distortions. algorithm constructs distance matrix element represents cost aligning points two series finds warping path matrix minimizes total distance. warping path contiguous monotonic, starting bottom-left corner ending top-right corner (Cleasby et al., 2019). DTW measures non-negative unbounded, larger values indicating greater dissimilarity time series. method used various contexts, including ecological studies analyze cluster trajectory data (Cleasby et al., 2019). Potential limitations biases DTW include sensitivity noise outliers, computational complexity, need appropriate distance metrics. Additionally, DTW may always account structural differences trajectories can biased chosen alignment constraints. DTW can handle trajectories different lengths due elastic nature, trajectories similar lengths can improve accuracy interpretability similarity measure. Similar lengths result meaningful alignment can make computation efficient. trajectories differ significantly length, preprocessing normalization might necessary, careful analysis required understand alignment path. function’s flexibility handling different lengths allows applied various contexts. However, large differences trajectory lengths might introduce potential biases considered interpreting results. function offers three different superposition methods align trajectories DTW() applied: "None": superposition applied. "Centroid": Trajectories shifted align based centroids. "Origin": Trajectories shifted align based starting point. test = TRUE, function can compute p-values comparing observed DTW distances generated set simulated trajectories. p-values calculated individual trajectory pairs entire set trajectories.

title: Similarity metric using Fréchet distance — simil_Frechet_metric
text: simil_Frechet_metric() function calculates similarity trajectories using Frechet() function SimilarityMeasures package. Fréchet distance measure similarity two curves continuous trajectories, takes account order location points within trajectories (Besse et al. 2015). distance can described analogy person walking dog extendable leash (Aronov et al. 2006). person dog move along respective trajectories, able adjust speed retrace steps. Fréchet distance minimum leash length required keep dog connected person throughout walk (Cleasby et al., 2019). Unlike trajectory comparison techniques, Dynamic Time Warping, Fréchet distance focuses overall shape trajectories rather matching specific points. result, sensitive noise points compared trajectories considered calculation. However, can still powerful tool trajectory clustering comparison, particularly shape primary concern (Cleasby et al., 2019). Note comparing real trajectories disparate simulated unconstrained method, resulting trajectories may suitable Fréchet distance calculations. cases, Fréchet distance returned -1 indicate invalid measurement. function offers three different superposition methods align trajectories Frechet() applied: "None": superposition applied. "Centroid": Trajectories shifted align based centroids. "Origin": Trajectories shifted align based starting point. test = TRUE, function can compute p-values comparing observed Fréchet distances generated set simulated trajectories. p-values calculated individual trajectory pairs entire set trajectories.

what: Simulate tracks using different models — simulate_track
title: Simulate tracks using different models — simulate_track
text: simulate_track() simulates movement trajectories based original set tracks. Three movement models available simulation, reflecting different levels constraint movement patterns. models can represent biological environmental constraints, movement along coastlines, rivers, towards resources like water food.

title: Simulate tracks using different models — simulate_track
code: simulate_track(data, nsim = NULL, model = NULL)

title: Simulate tracks using different models — simulate_track
text: data 'track' R object, list consisting two elements: Trajectories: list interpolated trajectories, trajectory series midpoints consecutive footprints. Footprints: list data frames containing footprint coordinates, metadata (e.g., image reference, ID), marker indicating whether footprint actual inferred. nsim number simulations run. Defaults 1000 specified. model type movement model use. Options "Directed", "Constrained", "Unconstrained". Defaults "Unconstrained" provided.

title: Simulate tracks using different models — simulate_track
text: 'track simulation' R object consisting list simulated trajectories stored 'track' R objects.

title: Simulate tracks using different models — simulate_track
text: function simulates movement trajectories based following models: Directed: model simulates movement follows specific direction navigating compass (.e., directed walk/allothetic directed walk/oriented path) (Cheung et al., 2007, 2008). trajectory constrained angular linear properties original track, minor deviations allowed reflect natural variability. Angular constraints: trajectory closely follows specific direction, maintaining overall angular orientation original track. Deviations consecutive steps governed angular standard deviation calculated original track using TrajAngles(). Linear constraints: Step lengths constrained mean original track's step lengths, variability allowed according standard deviation step lengths computed TrajStepLengths(). Starting direction: Fixed original direction (overall angular orientation) track. model ideal simulating movement directed toward specific resource constrained natural barriers, relatively fixed direction minor deviations. Constrained: model simulates movement correspond correllated random walk/idiothetic directed walk (Kareiva & Shigesada, 1983), corresponding animal navigating without compass (Cheung et al., 2008), still maintaining certain angular linear characteristics original track. provides flexibility Directed model entirely random like Unconstrained model. Angular constraints: trajectory follow specific direction. Deviations consecutive steps governed angular standard deviation calculated original track using TrajAngles(). Linear constraints: Step lengths constrained mean original track's step lengths, variability allowed according standard deviation step lengths computed TrajStepLengths(). Starting direction: Fixed original direction (overall angular orientation) track. model suitable scenarios movement influenced external constraints allows degree random exploration. Unconstrained: model simulates movement correspond correllated random walk/idiothetic directed walk (Kareiva & Shigesada, 1983), corresponding animal navigating without compass (Cheung et al., 2008), still maintaining certain angular linear characteristics original track. Angular constraints: trajectory follow specific direction. Deviations consecutive steps governed angular standard deviation calculated original track using TrajAngles(). Linear constraints: Step lengths constrained mean original track's step lengths, variability allowed according standard deviation step lengths computed TrajStepLengths(). Starting direction: Randomly determined. model suitable simulating exploratory dispersal behavior open environments, movement random influenced specific constraints. Note: Simulations applied trajectories fewer four steps standard deviations angles step lengths computed short trajectories. Consider using subset_track() function filter tracks four steps. function utilizes trajr package key calculations: TrajGenerate(): Generates new trajectory based random directed movement models, constrained specified parameters. TrajStepLengths(): Calculates step lengths (distances consecutive points) original trajectory. TrajAngles(): Computes angles consecutive segments trajectory, used maintain directional movement constrained models. TrajRotate(): Rotates trajectory specified angle match original direction random angle unconstrained models. TrajTranslate(): Translates simulated trajectory start geographic location original. NISTdegTOradian() function NISTunits package used convert angles degrees radians.

title: Simulate tracks using different models — simulate_track
text: Cheung, ., Zhang, S., Stricker, C., & Srinivasan, M. V. (2007). Animal navigation: difficulty moving straight line. Biological cybernetics, 97, 47-61. Cheung, ., Zhang, S., Stricker, C., & Srinivasan, M. V. (2008). Animal navigation: general properties directed walks. Biological cybernetics, 99, 197-217.

title: Simulate tracks using different models — simulate_track
text: Humberto G. Ferrón humberto.ferron@uv.es Macroevolution Functional Morphology Research Group (www.macrofun.es) Cavanilles Institute Biodiversity Evolutionary Biology Calle Catedrático José Beltrán Martínez, nº 2 46980 Paterna - Valencia - Spain Phone: +34 (9635) 44477

title: Simulate tracks using different models — simulate_track
code: # Example 1: Simulate tracks using data from the Paluxy River # Default model (Unconstrained movement) # Default number of simulations (1000) simulated_tracks <- simulate_track(PaluxyRiver) #> Warning: `nsim` is NULL. Using default value of 1000. #> Warning: `model` is NULL. Defaulting to 'Unconstrained'.  # Example 2: Simulate 100 tracks using the "Directed" model, representing movement # toward a resource (e.g., water source) simulated_tracks_directed <- simulate_track(PaluxyRiver, nsim = 10, model = "Directed")  # Example 3: Simulate 100 tracks using the "Constrained" model, representing movement # along a geographic feature (e.g., coastline) simulated_tracks_constrained <- simulate_track(PaluxyRiver, nsim = 10, model = "Constrained")  # Example 4: Simulate 100 tracks using the "Unconstrained" model (random exploratory movement) simulated_tracks_unconstrained <- simulate_track(PaluxyRiver, nsim = 10, model = "Unconstrained")  # Subsetting trajectories with four or more steps in the MountTom dataset sbMountTom <- subset_track(MountTom, tracks = c(1, 2, 3, 4, 7, 8, 9, 13, 15, 16, 18))  # Example 5: Simulate tracks using data from Mount Tom # Default model (Unconstrained movement) # Default number of simulations (1000) simulated_tracks_mt <- simulate_track(sbMountTom) #> Warning: `nsim` is NULL. Using default value of 1000. #> Warning: `model` is NULL. Defaulting to 'Unconstrained'.  # Example 6: Simulate 100 tracks using the "Directed" model for Mount Tom, representing # directed movement simulated_tracks_mt_directed <- simulate_track(sbMountTom, nsim = 10, model = "Directed")  # Example 7: Simulate 100 tracks using the "Constrained" model for Mount Tom, representing # constrained movement simulated_tracks_mt_constrained <- simulate_track(sbMountTom, nsim = 10, model = "Constrained")  # Example 8: Simulate 100 tracks using the "Unconstrained" model for Mount Tom, representing # random exploratory movement simulated_tracks_mt_unconstrained <- simulate_track(sbMountTom, nsim = 10, model = "Unconstrained")

title: Subset tracks — subset_track
text: subset_track() function subsets tracks list track data based specified indices.

title: Subset tracks — subset_track
code: subset_track(data, tracks = NULL)

title: Subset tracks — subset_track
text: data 'track' R object, list consisting two elements: Trajectories: list interpolated trajectories, trajectory series midpoints consecutive footprints. Footprints: list data frames containing footprint coordinates, metadata (e.g., image reference, ID), marker indicating whether footprint actual inferred. tracks numeric vector specifying indices tracks subset. default include tracks.

title: Subset tracks — subset_track
text: 'track' R object contains specified subset tracks. structure returned object mirrors input structure includes selected tracks.

title: Subset tracks — subset_track
text: function subsets Trajectories Footprints elements input data based provided vector indices. allows users focus specific subset tracks analysis visualization, particularly working large datasets containing numerous tracks.

title: Subset tracks — subset_track
text: Humberto G. Ferrón humberto.ferron@uv.es Macroevolution Functional Morphology Research Group (www.macrofun.es) Cavanilles Institute Biodiversity Evolutionary Biology Calle Catedrático José Beltrán Martínez, nº 2 46980 Paterna - Valencia - Spain Phone: +34 (9635) 44477

title: Subset tracks — subset_track
code: # Example 1: Subset the first three tracks of MountTom dataset. subset_data <- subset_track(MountTom, tracks = c(1:3))  # Example 2:  Subset the tracks at indices 5, 7, and 10. subset_data <- subset_track(MountTom, tracks = c(5, 7, 10))

what: Test for Differences in Direction Means with Pairwise Comparisons — test_direction
title: Test for Differences in Direction Means with Pairwise Comparisons — test_direction
text: test_direction() evaluates differences mean direction across different tracks using specified statistical test. includes options ANOVA, Kruskal-Wallis test, Generalized Linear Models (GLM), checks assumptions normality homogeneity variances. datasets two tracks, performs pairwise comparisons identify specific differences tracks.

title: Test for Differences in Direction Means with Pairwise Comparisons — test_direction
code: test_direction(data, analysis = NULL)

title: Test for Differences in Direction Means with Pairwise Comparisons — test_direction
text: data 'track' R object, list consisting two elements: Trajectories: list interpolated trajectories, trajectory series midpoints consecutive footprints. Footprints: list data frames containing footprint coordinates, metadata (e.g., image reference, ID), marker indicating whether footprint actual inferred. analysis character string specifying type analysis: "ANOVA", "Kruskal-Wallis", "GLM". Default "ANOVA".

title: Test for Differences in Direction Means with Pairwise Comparisons — test_direction
text: list results statistical analysis diagnostic tests: normality_results: matrix test statistics p-values Shapiro-Wilk test track, rows test statistic p-value, columns track. homogeneity_test: result Levene's test, including p-value homogeneity variances. ANOVA (analysis "ANOVA"): list containing ANOVA table Tukey HSD post-hoc test results. Kruskal_Wallis (analysis "Kruskal-Wallis"): list containing Kruskal-Wallis test result Dunn's test post-hoc results. GLM (analysis "GLM"): summary GLM fit pairwise comparisons.

title: Test for Differences in Direction Means with Pairwise Comparisons — test_direction
text: test_direction() function performs following operations: Condition Testing: Normality: Shapiro-Wilk test normality step direction data within track. Homogeneity Variances: Levene's test equal variances across tracks. Statistical Analysis: ANOVA: Compares step mean directions across tracks, assuming normality homogeneity variances. Includes Tukey's HSD post-hoc test pairwise comparisons. Kruskal-Wallis Test: Non-parametric alternative ANOVA comparing step median directions across tracks assumptions violated. Includes Dunn's test pairwise comparisons. GLM: Generalized Linear Model Gaussian family comparing step means ANOVA assumptions met. Pairwise comparisons GLM conducted using estimated marginal means (least-squares means) emmeans package, computes differences group means adjusting multiple comparisons using Tukey’s method. Direction Measurement: direction measured degrees. reference direction, 0 degrees, considered along positive x-axis. Angles measured counterclockwise positive x-axis, 0 degrees pointing directly along axis.

title: Test for Differences in Direction Means with Pairwise Comparisons — test_direction
text: Humberto G. Ferrón humberto.ferron@uv.es Macroevolution Functional Morphology Research Group (www.macrofun.es) Cavanilles Institute Biodiversity Evolutionary Biology Calle Catedrático José Beltrán Martínez, nº 2 46980 Paterna - Valencia - Spain Phone: +34 (9635) 44477

title: Test for Differences in Direction Means with Pairwise Comparisons — test_direction

what: Test for differences in velocity means with pairwise comparisons — test_velocity
title: Test for differences in velocity means with pairwise comparisons — test_velocity
text: test_velocity() evaluates differences velocity means across different tracks using specified statistical test. includes options ANOVA, Kruskal-Wallis test, Generalized Linear Models (GLM), checks assumptions normality homogeneity variances. datasets two tracks, performs pairwise comparisons identify specific differences tracks.

title: Test for differences in velocity means with pairwise comparisons — test_velocity
code: test_velocity(data, trackvel, plot = FALSE, analysis = NULL)

title: Test for differences in velocity means with pairwise comparisons — test_velocity
text: data 'track' R object, list consisting two elements: Trajectories: list interpolated trajectories, trajectory series midpoints consecutive footprints. Footprints: list data frames containing footprint coordinates, metadata (e.g., image reference, ID), marker indicating whether footprint actual inferred. trackvel 'track velocity' R object consisting list element corresponds track contains velocity relative stride length data. plot logical value indicating whether plot boxplot velocities track (default FALSE). analysis character string specifying type analysis: "ANOVA", "Kruskal-Wallis", "GLM". Default "ANOVA".

title: Test for differences in velocity means with pairwise comparisons — test_velocity
text: list results statistical analysis diagnostic tests: normality_results: matrix test statistics p-values Shapiro-Wilk test track, rows test statistic p-value, columns track. homogeneity_test: result Levene's test, including p-value homogeneity variances. ANOVA (analysis "ANOVA"): list containing ANOVA table Tukey HSD post-hoc test results. Kruskal_Wallis (analysis "Kruskal-Wallis"): list containing Kruskal-Wallis test result Dunn's test post-hoc results. GLM (analysis "GLM"): summary GLM fit pairwise comparisons. plot (plot TRUE): boxplot velocities track generated displayed.

title: Test for differences in velocity means with pairwise comparisons — test_velocity
text: test_velocity function performs following operations: Condition Testing: Normality: Shapiro-Wilk test normality velocity data within track. Homogeneity Variances: Levene's test equal variances across tracks. Statistical Analysis: ANOVA: Compares mean velocities across tracks, assuming normality homogeneity variances. Includes Tukey's HSD post-hoc test pairwise comparisons. Kruskal-Wallis Test: Non-parametric alternative ANOVA comparing median velocities across tracks assumptions violated. Includes Dunn's test pairwise comparisons. GLM: Generalized Linear Model Gaussian family comparing means ANOVA assumptions met. Pairwise comparisons GLM conducted using estimated marginal means (least-squares means) emmeans package, computes differences group means adjusting multiple comparisons using Tukey’s method. Plotting: plot TRUE, boxplot velocities track generated.

what: Transform a *.tps file into a 'track' R object — tps_to_track
title: Transform a *.tps file into a 'track' R object — tps_to_track
text: tps_to_track() reads *.tps file containing footprint coordinates one several tracks transforms 'track' R object.

title: Transform a *.tps file into a 'track' R object — tps_to_track
code: tps_to_track(file, scale = NULL, missing = FALSE, NAs = NULL, R.L.side = NULL)

title: Transform a *.tps file into a 'track' R object — tps_to_track
text: file *.tps file containing (x,y) coordinates footprints tracks. scale numeric value specifying scale meters per pixel. missing logical value indicating whether missing footprints track interpolated: TRUE, FALSE (default). NAs matrix two columns indicating missing footprints interpolated. first column gives number track containing missing footprints, second column gives number footprint missing within track. number rows equal total number missing footprints sample. R.L.side character vector specifying side first footprint track. needed missing set TRUE. length vector must equal total number tracks sample. "L": first footprint corresponds left foot. "R": first footprint corresponds right foot.

title: Transform a *.tps file into a 'track' R object — tps_to_track
text: 'track' R object, list consisting two elements: Trajectories: list interpolated trajectories, trajectory series midpoints consecutive footprints. Footprints: list data frames containing footprint coordinates, metadata (e.g., image reference, ID), marker indicating whether footprint actual inferred.

title: Transform a *.tps file into a 'track' R object — tps_to_track
text: highly recommended *.tps file built using TPS software (Rohlf 2008, 2009). Tracks different number footprints (.e., landmarks) allowed. function transforms coordinates footprints track set trajectory coordinates. point trajectory calculated : $$Point_i(x,y)= (Footprint_i(x,y) + Footprint_{+1}(x,y)/2$$ number points resulting trajectory \(n_{footprints} - 1\). missing set TRUE, missing footprints can interpolated. interpolation based adjacent footprints provided side information.

title: Transform a *.tps file into a 'track' R object — tps_to_track
text: Farlow, J. O., O’Brien, M., Kuban, G. J., Dattilo, B. F., Bates, K. T., Falkingham, P. L., & Piñuela, L. (2012). Dinosaur Tracksites Paluxy River Valley (Glen Rose Formation, Lower Cretaceous), Dinosaur Valley State Park, Somervell County, Texas. Proceedings V International Symposium Dinosaur Palaeontology Environment (pp. 41-69). Burgos: Salas de los Infantes. Ostrom, J. H. (1972). dinosaurs gregarious?. Palaeogeography, Palaeoclimatology, Palaeoecology, 11(4), 287-301. Rohlf, F. J. 2008. TPSUTIL. Version 1.40. Department Ecology Evolution, State University New York. Available https://sbmorphometrics.org/. Rohlf, F. J. 2009. tpsDig. Version 2.14. Department Ecology Evolution, State University New York. Available https://sbmorphometrics.org/.

title: Transform a *.tps file into a 'track' R object — tps_to_track
